metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Using combined MS, IR, and NMR data to deduce organic compound structures

ms-role.name: MS Role in Analysis
ms-role.correct: MS provides molecular mass from M+ peak and structural fragments from fragmentation pattern

gives functional groups only.fix: MS gives molecular mass and fragmentation; IR identifies functional groups
gives functional groups only.action: MS = mass and fragments; IR = functional groups

gives carbon environments.fix: MS gives mass information; ¹³C-NMR gives carbon environments
gives carbon environments.action: MS = mass; NMR = environments and structure

requires reference standards.fix: MS provides mass data directly; HPLC needs standards for identification
requires reference standards.action: MS is self-interpretive for mass; HPLC uses retention time comparison

persistent.gap: Not recognising MS provides molecular mass and fragmentation patterns
persistent.action: Start with MS: molecular mass narrows down molecular formula

ir-role.name: IR Role in Analysis
ir-role.correct: IR identifies functional groups from characteristic absorption bands

gives molecular mass.fix: IR identifies functional groups; MS gives molecular mass
gives molecular mass.action: IR = functional groups (O-H, C=O, etc.); MS = molecular mass

gives number of carbons.fix: IR shows functional groups; ¹³C-NMR shows carbon environments
gives number of carbons.action: IR = what groups are present; NMR = how atoms are arranged

identifies specific compounds directly.fix: IR identifies functional groups but usually needs other data for complete identification
identifies specific compounds directly.action: IR fingerprint can match spectra but works best with MS and NMR

persistent.gap: Not using IR specifically for functional group identification
persistent.action: Use IR to identify: O-H, N-H, C=O, C-H, and other functional groups

nmr-role.name: NMR Role in Analysis
nmr-role.correct: NMR reveals number of unique environments and molecular connectivity

gives molecular mass.fix: NMR shows atomic environments; MS gives molecular mass
gives molecular mass.action: NMR = environments and structure; MS = mass

identifies functional groups only.fix: NMR shows environments and connectivity; IR identifies functional groups
identifies functional groups only.action: NMR reveals WHERE atoms are; IR reveals WHAT groups are present

only works for one nucleus.fix: Both ¹H and ¹³C NMR provide complementary structural information
only works for one nucleus.action: Use ¹H-NMR for protons (integration, splitting) and ¹³C-NMR for carbons

persistent.gap: Not recognising NMR provides detailed structural information
persistent.action: NMR shows: environments, relative numbers (¹H), and connectivity (splitting)

analysis-order.name: Order of Analysis
analysis-order.correct: Start with MS (molecular formula), then IR (functional groups), then NMR (structure details)

start with NMR always.fix: Start with MS for molecular formula; NMR details come after knowing what's present
start with NMR always.action: MS first (how heavy), IR second (what groups), NMR last (how connected)

any order works equally well.fix: Starting with MS narrows possibilities; IR confirms groups; NMR finalises structure
any order works equally well.action: Each technique builds on previous: mass → groups → structure

one technique is sufficient.fix: Complete structure determination usually requires multiple techniques
one technique is sufficient.action: Combine all three for confident structural assignment

persistent.action: Follow: MS (molecular mass) → IR (functional groups) → NMR (detailed structure)

molecular-formula.name: Molecular Formula from MS
molecular-formula.correct: The M+ peak gives molecular mass; calculate degree of unsaturation to predict rings/double bonds

base peak gives molecular mass.error: Confusing base peak with M+ peak
base peak gives molecular mass.fix: M+ (molecular ion) gives molecular mass; base peak is most intense (may or may not be M+)
base peak gives molecular mass.action: Look for M+ peak (usually at high mass end); base peak may be a fragment

molecular mass alone identifies compound.fix: Many compounds share the same molecular mass; need IR and NMR to distinguish
molecular mass alone identifies compound.action: Same mass could be different isomers; other techniques needed

fragment peaks are errors.fix: Fragments reveal structural information about which bonds break
fragment peaks are errors.action: Fragments help identify molecular features and connectivity

persistent.gap: Not extracting full information from MS data
persistent.action: Use M+ for formula, fragments for structure hints, then confirm with IR/NMR

functional-group-evidence.name: Functional Group Evidence
functional-group-evidence.correct: Combine IR peaks with NMR chemical shifts to confirm functional groups

IR alone is definitive.fix: IR suggests functional groups; NMR chemical shifts confirm and locate them
IR alone is definitive.action: IR shows O-H at 3300 cm⁻¹; NMR confirms with peak position and shape

NMR alone identifies all groups.fix: NMR shows chemical shifts but IR better distinguishes similar groups
NMR alone identifies all groups.action: IR clearly distinguishes C=O types (aldehyde, ketone, ester, acid)

functional groups don't affect other spe.fix: Functional groups affect MS fragmentation, IR bands, and NMR shifts
functional groups don't affect other spe.action: Look for consistent evidence across all techniques

persistent.gap: Not cross-referencing functional group evidence across techniques
persistent.action: Confirm each group with multiple techniques: IR bands + NMR shifts + MS fragments

structure-assembly.name: Assembling the Structure
structure-assembly.correct: Combine molecular formula, functional groups, and connectivity to deduce complete structure

guess and check randomly.fix: Use data systematically: formula limits options, groups narrow further, NMR confirms
guess and check randomly.action: Methodical approach: each piece of data eliminates wrong structures

ignore contradictory evidence.fix: All data must be consistent with proposed structure; contradictions indicate errors
ignore contradictory evidence.action: If one technique contradicts, reconsider the structure

stop at first possible structure.fix: Check proposed structure against ALL spectroscopic data
stop at first possible structure.action: Verify: does structure explain all peaks in MS, IR, and NMR?

persistent.gap: Not systematically assembling structure from all evidence
persistent.action: Propose structure, then verify against every piece of spectroscopic data

isomer-distinction.name: Distinguishing Isomers
isomer-distinction.correct: Isomers share molecular formula but differ in NMR patterns and some IR features

MS distinguishes all isomers.error: MS gives same M+ for isomers
MS distinguishes all isomers.fix: Isomers have same molecular mass; need NMR to distinguish them
MS distinguishes all isomers.action: Same M+ → same formula → use NMR peak count and splitting to distinguish

isomers have identical IR spectra.fix: Different functional groups give different IR (e.g., ketone vs aldehyde)
isomers have identical IR spectra.action: Positional isomers may differ in IR if environments change

only one isomer is possible.fix: Most molecular formulas have multiple possible isomers
only one isomer is possible.action: Always consider isomers and use spectroscopic data to choose correct one

persistent.gap: Not recognising isomer possibilities and how to distinguish them
persistent.action: NMR is key for isomers: different peak counts and patterns

sentences.text: Mass spectrometry provides the {{d1}} mass from the M+ peak and {{d2}} patterns from bond breaking.

d1.tooltip: MS gives molecular mass from M+

sentences.text: Infrared spectroscopy identifies {{d1}} groups from characteristic {{d2}} bands in the spectrum.

d2.tooltip: Functional groups absorb at characteristic wavenumbers

sentences.text: NMR spectroscopy reveals the number of {{d1}} environments and, in ¹H-NMR, the {{d2}} between them.
A systematic approach starts with {{d1}} to determine molecular formula, then {{d2}} to identify functional groups, and finally {{d3}} for detailed structure.
The M+ peak in MS gives {{d1}} mass. The degree of unsaturation helps predict {{d2}} bonds and {{d3}}.
Each technique provides {{d1}} information. Combining all three gives {{d2}} confidence in the structure.
Confirming a functional group requires evidence from {{d1}} technique(s). For example, an alcohol shows O-H in {{d2}} and a peak around {{d3}} ppm in ¹H-NMR.

d3.tooltip: Alcohol O-H appears in this region

sentences.text: To assemble the structure, identify the {{d1}} formula first, then determine what {{d2}} groups are present, and finally work out how they are {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: Start with molecular formula from MS

sentences.text: Isomers have the same {{d1}} mass but different {{d2}} patterns, making NMR essential for distinguishing them.
A chemist analyses an unknown with M+ at 88. This {{d1}} mass suggests a molecular formula of C₄H₈O₂. The even mass indicates an {{d2}} number of nitrogen atoms (likely {{d3}}).

d3.tooltip: No nitrogen suggested by even mass

sentences.text: The IR spectrum shows a strong peak at 1735 cm⁻¹ indicating {{d1}}. This rules out {{d2}} as a possible structure because they show C=O at different {{d3}}.

d3.tooltip: Different carbonyl types absorb at different wavenumbers

sentences.text: The ¹H-NMR shows two signals: a triplet at δ 1.2 ppm (3H) and a quartet at δ 4.1 ppm (2H). This pattern indicates an {{d1}} group with the CH₂ {{d2}} to oxygen.
An unknown has molecular formula C₃H₆O (from MS). The IR shows a strong {{d1}} peak at 1720 cm⁻¹ but no {{d2}} absorption around 3400 cm⁻¹. This suggests the compound is a {{d3}}, not an alcohol.

d3.tooltip: C=O without O-H suggests carbonyl compound

sentences.text: The ¹³C-NMR of C₃H₆O shows 3 peaks, confirming {{d1}} different carbon environments. Combined with MS molecular mass and IR carbonyl peak, the structure can be deduced as {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: 3 different C in CHO, CH₂, CH₃

sentences.text: For C₃H₆O, both propanal and propanone have the same {{d1}}. To distinguish them, check ¹H-NMR for an aldehyde proton around {{d2}} ppm, which would appear as a {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: Same formula = same MS M+ peak

d3.tooltip: CHO coupling depends on adjacent H

sentences.text: Combining evidence: MS M+ = 60, IR shows broad O-H at 3350 cm⁻¹, ¹H-NMR shows quartet at 3.6 ppm and triplet at 1.2 ppm. The compound is {{d1}}. The ethyl group is confirmed by the {{d2}} pattern.
When the proposed structure is complete, verify it explains: the M+ {{d1}} in MS, all {{d2}} bands in IR, the number of {{d3}} in NMR, and the splitting {{d4}}.

d2.tooltip: All IR peaks must be explained

sentences.text: Structural isomers like propan-1-ol and propan-2-ol share MS M+ at {{d1}} but differ in NMR: propan-1-ol shows {{d2}} signals while propan-2-ol shows {{d3}} signals.

A forensic chemist receives an unknown white powder. MS shows M+ at {{d1}} with fragments at 77 and 105. The fragment at 77 suggests a {{d2}} ring. IR shows C=O at 1690 cm⁻¹. ¹H-NMR shows peaks in the {{d3}} region (7.4-8.0 ppm) and a singlet at 2.6 ppm. The compound is likely {{d4}}.

The mass spectrum shows M+ = 74 with a base peak at 45 (loss of {{d1}}). IR shows broad O-H at 3400 cm⁻¹ and C=O at 1710 cm⁻¹. This combination indicates a {{d2}}. The ¹³C-NMR shows {{d3}} peaks, confirming the structure as {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: CH₃COOH = M 60... wait, M=74 suggests propanoic acid

sentences.text: For complete structure determination, the chemist records: MS (molecular mass = {{d1}} and fragments), IR (functional groups = C=O at {{d2}}), ¹H-NMR ({{d3}} patterns), and ¹³C-NMR ({{d4}} environments). Each technique provides {{d5}} information.

d5.tooltip: Techniques provide different types of information

sentences.text: Two compounds both show M+ = 88 and C=O in IR. Compound A shows 4 ¹³C peaks; compound B shows 3 ¹³C peaks. Compound B has {{d1}} due to {{d2}}. If compound A is butanoic acid, compound B could be {{d3}}.

d3.tooltip: Branched structure has equivalent CH₃ groups

sentences.text: A pharmaceutical company analyses a synthetic drug. MS: M+ = 151. IR: N-H at 3350 cm⁻¹, C=O at 1650 cm⁻¹. ¹H-NMR: aromatic peaks (5H) at 7.3 ppm, singlet (2H) at 4.5 ppm, broad (2H) at 6.5 ppm. The {{d1}} indicates an amide, the {{d2}} pattern confirms a phenyl ring, and the compound is likely {{d3}}.

Final verification: the proposed structure must explain {{d1}} observed features. Check that the molecular formula from MS matches, all IR {{d2}} are assigned, and NMR {{d3}} counts and {{d4}} patterns are consistent. If any data doesn't fit, the structure must be {{d5}}.

explanations.ms-role: MS provides molecular mass from M+ peak and structural information from fragmentation patterns.
explanations.ir-role: IR identifies functional groups through characteristic absorption bands at specific wavenumbers.
explanations.nmr-role: NMR reveals atomic environments, relative numbers (¹H integration), and connectivity (splitting).
explanations.analysis-order: Systematic analysis: MS (molecular formula) → IR (functional groups) → NMR (structure details).
explanations.molecular-formula: M+ gives molecular mass; degree of unsaturation predicts rings and double bonds.
explanations.functional-group-evidence: Confirm functional groups using multiple techniques: IR bands, NMR shifts, and MS fragments.
explanations.structure-assembly: Combine all spectroscopic data systematically; verify proposed structure against every observation.
explanations.isomer-distinction: Isomers share molecular mass but differ in NMR patterns; use peak count and splitting to distinguish.
